title: 108_hr2038
content: The Act is titled the "Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2003". It includes definitions for various terms. The term 'semiautomatic assault weapon' is defined in the Assault Weapons Ban and Law Enforcement Protection Act of 2003 as including specific rifles such as AK-47, AR-15, and M1 Carbine. The list of semiautomatic assault weapons includes M1 Carbine, Saiga, SAR-8, SKS with detachable magazine, SLG 95, SLR 95, Steyr AUG, Mini-14, Tavor, Thompson 1927, Uzi, Calico M-110, MAC-10, Olympic Arms OA, TEC-9, and Uzi. The list of semiautomatic assault weapons includes Armscor 30 BG, SPAS 12, LAW 12, Striker 12, Streetsweeper, and various semiautomatic rifles with specific features like detachable magazines, folding or telescoping stocks, threaded barrels, pistol grips, forward grips, and barrel shrouds. The list of semiautomatic assault weapons includes devices designed for .22 caliber rimfire ammunition, semiautomatic pistols with specific features like detachable magazines, second pistol grips, threaded barrels, barrel shrouds, or fixed magazines with capacity over 10 rounds, and semiautomatic shotguns with folding or telescoping stocks, pistol grips, ability to accept detachable magazines, or fixed magazine capacity over 5 rounds. The list of prohibited semiautomatic assault weapons includes firearms with revolving cylinders, frames or receivers based on specified firearms, conversion kits, and military or law enforcement designed rifles or shotguns not suitable for sporting purposes. The definition of "barrel shroud" and "conversion kit" are added to the related definitions in Section 921(a) of the title. The barrel shroud is a protective attachment for the barrel of a firearm, while a conversion kit is parts intended to convert a firearm into a semiautomatic assault weapon. The curr_chunk defines terms related to firearms, including detachable magazine, fixed magazine, folding or telescoping stock, forward grip, and pistol grip. The curr_chunk defines "pistol grip" as a grip or thumbhole stock that can function as a grip, and "threaded barrel" as a feature designed to attach a firearm. SEC. 3 amends Section 110105 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 by eliminating the sunset provision. SEC. 4 amends Section 922(v)(2) of title 18, US Code, with grandfather provisions. SEC. 5 repeals certain exemptions. SEC. 5 repeals certain exemptions related to firearms, specifying that certain types of firearms are not subject to certain regulations. SEC. 6 requires background checks for the transfer of semiautomatic assault weapons. Section 922(v) of title 18, United States Code is amended to prohibit the transfer of semiautomatic assault weapons except through licensed dealers or state/local law enforcement agencies following specific procedures. The Attorney General is required to maintain records of these weapons. The Attorney General must maintain records of any semiautomatic assault weapon used in a crime and submit an annual report to Congress, making the information public. SEC. 7 strengthens the ban on large capacity ammunition feeding devices. The text amends Section 922 of title 18, United States Code to prohibit the transfer of assault weapons with large capacity ammunition feeding devices. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both. Additionally, a certification requirement is amended for firearms in the United States before September 13, 1994. The text amends Section 922 of title 18, United States Code to prohibit the transfer of large capacity ammunition feeding devices for assault weapons manufactured before September 13, 1994. Violators must certify to the Attorney General within 60 days of transfer. Penalties under Section 924(a) include fines and imprisonment up to 10 years. The amendment adds penalties for knowingly violating the prohibition on transferring large capacity ammunition feeding devices for assault weapons. Offenders may face fines, imprisonment for up to 5 years, or both. SEC. 8 amends Section 922(x) of title 18, United States Code to include penalties for transferring semiautomatic assault weapons or large capacity ammunition feeding devices to juveniles. SEC. 9 bans the importation of large capacity ammunition feeding devices. SEC. 9 amends Section 922(w) of title 18, United States Code to prohibit the importation of large capacity ammunition feeding devices.
